title: Will Rex Tillerson be confirmed by the Senate as secretary of state before 30 April 2017?
preds:
Rex Tillerson confirmed as top US diplomat

Tillerson is a fine example of swamp draining and repudiation of the elites, or at
least of the oddity of the political situation in the US.   He will be confirmed,  
Deomcrats will not be able to block it.  Republicans will fall in line sufficiently
that he will be confirmed.  It will be great for the oil industry and a disaster for 
the US and the planet.    Freed of Dod-Frank limits on bribery and of state dept 
approbation it will be a great, great time to make deals before all the wheels
come off. Sigh. News tonight 2/1 says the Senate has approved.   No longer a prediction.
Republican majority in the Senate, and Rex Tillerson is not as controversial as many there cabinet choices. He definitely gets the votes.

Possible that the Senate could vote on Rex Tillerson today. According to the floor activity yesterday (January 31st), under executive business, Rex Tillerson was being considered by senate. The senate adjourned that evening and will resume the executive session at 12:00 (EST) today.
Given that all other Trump nominees are on track to be confirmed, it makes a lot of logical and Bayesian sense to think that Tillerson would be confirmed too. I put this at 99%

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-congress-tillerson-idUSKBN15E2SW
A floor vote is imminent.  So are many other things, about which it is best not to think too much.
Looks like Ds are saving up their limited energy for the Supreme Court seat.  I think it's time to rename the major parties:  How about the Chaoticists and the Futilitarians?
This Jan. 30 CNN article, http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/30/politics/tillerson-nomination-advances/, gives an update on the process.
A confirmation vote has just been cleared of filibuster, and may take place as early as this week (http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/30/politics/tillerson-nomination-advances/).
could be in less than a month.

Senators voted 56-43 to put Tillerson's bid to be the nation's chief diplomat on track for confirmation later this week
http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/world-news/trumps-nominee-for-state-clears-procedural-hurdle-in-senate/articleshow/56882784.cms Done and dusted.

Confirmation vote may be set for Wednesday.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-congress-tillerson-idUSKBN15E2SW?il=0
key senators have already agreed to support and with Republican majority he will be confirmed

Sadly yes. Even if every Democrat stands firm against it, there are no Republicans with the ability to think for themselves  . . . or to come to any conclusion which might be good for the country even if it crosses Donald Trump.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

A bit of a "black swan," though really not so much, might be what could happen regarding outcomes of investigations into Russian activities by Senate and House intelligence committees, and the reported U.S. IC joint-agency working group looking into the same things.  The U.S. press is today starting to look at this recent news item. It has been in UK media for a couple of days, and covered somewhat by Canadian, Australian and Israeli media: “Mystery surrounds death of former KGB chief linked to lurid Trump report,” Kansas City Star, Jan. 29, http://www.kansascity.com/news/nation-world/world/article129453019.html.

1. There is a 95% success rate of confirmation for nominees of all cabinet positions since Carter (the expansion to the modern cabinet with HHS and other cabinet level positions)
2. The range of length of time for confirmation has ranged from 13 days to 101 days (Obama - Kathleen Sebelius) 
3. Rex Tillerson has made out of Committee - increasing the likelihood of confirmation

Up after:
Former ExxonMobil chief executive Rex Tillerson won the backing of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee Monday to be secretary of state when it voted 11-10 to send his nomination to the full Senate.
Senate is toothless and cowed by Trump's victory. Republicans too scared to challenge Trump.
Big oil seems to be running the show. A lot of house & senate members are influenced by the oil industry.
Republicans are pretty united on this and there is no filibuster.
With Rubio and McCain on board this is a sure thing.
The Democrats can't filibuster this nomination, so they'll all vote against him, and he'll be confirmed on a straight party-line vote long before April 30.
Republican control of House and Senate
He's been reported out of Committee and has no Republican opposition and some Democratic support (Senator Manchin); this will more than uarantee his confirmation before the end of January.

Unless additional information surfaces about oil deals with Putin and friends, it seems likely he'll be confirmed. Related article: "Memos: CEO of Russia's state oil company offered Trump adviser, allies a cut of huge deal if sanctions were lifted,” Business Insider, Jan. 27, http://www.businessinsider.com/carter-page-trump-russia-igor-sechin-dossier-2017-1

Going down a bit, in response to (a) the numerous resignations of State Dept senior officials, (b) rumours that the US may lift sanctions against Russia imposed after the annexation of Crimea. This would not meet with universal approval among GOP lawmakers.
A rumoured leak of Trump dropping Crimea sanctions on Russia won't go over well with enough R senators to possibly hold up Tillerson. I'm going down until the dust clears.

I know, you know, we all know how corrupt this man is just by looking at a few pictures of him with some buisness partners, and close friends. Vladimir Putin. Sadly however I would not put it past Trump to ignore Majority opinion and through recent republican controversies and their majority in government will most likely confirm him. here's hoping for the 38%.
Top republicans agreed to vote for him meaning that the chances of him not geting nominated have greatly decreased.

Not sure if this will have an impact: "The State Department’s entire senior management team just resigned,” Washington Post, Jan. 16, https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/josh-rogin/wp/2017/01/26/the-state-departments-entire-senior-management-team-just-resigned/?utm_term=.9911eac7e2fc&wpisrc=nl_most-draw7&wpmm=1 Additionally, we don't know what might come out of Senate and House intelligence committee's investigations into Russian connections and activities. A U.S. joint-agency counterintelligence task force is also reportedly looking into this. Related Jan. 25 article on Lawfare: “What Do We Know About Investigations Into Trump Associates’ Ties to Russia?” at https://www.lawfareblog.com/what-do-we-know-about-investigations-trump-associates-ties-russia
Very high. There aren't enough republicans with integrity to block him over conflicts of interest.
Tillerson is the second best cabinet member Trump has put forward, after Mattis. The senate would be stupid to shelve him.
He has the support of important business people such as Elon Musk, etc and that will help Tillerson to be confirmed by the Senate as it would be more complicated for them to say no

I may have an EXTREMELY low opinion of Trump, but because of the claims about Russian involvement throughout the election, I don't think that he is willing to risk his own head by letting Rex Tillerson, who has ties with Russia, to be Secretary of State.

Tillerson's ties to Russia are concerning to some senators and others, but he is getting through the confirmation process. Many people reportedly see him as a better alternative to John Bolton or someone like Bolton.
All the Senators needed for this have crawled into line.  Should happen soon.

Senate Democrats will not expend political capital trying to get their Republican colleagues to block this nominee, and some Democratic Senators may actually vote in favor of Tillerson in order to build goodwill with the President and their Republican colleagues.
Upping my forecast to 99% because Rubio, McCain, and Graham have all come out in support of Tillerson so the path for him to get confirmed is clear.
Tillerson will be confirmed within the next week or two. There is no way that the Conservatives can stop the Republicans.
Updating forecast from 93 to 97%. With McCain and Graham on board, and all other senate Republicans, there does not appear to be any hurdle to him being confirmed. Rubio could slow it down at most.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Key republicans have fallen in line.
I'm increasing my odds given the Trump administrations success at enacting policy and the senate's apparent approval.
The potential Republican holdouts in the Senate have fallen into line.
I believe it to be likely due to previous events such as the fact he passed the first phase.
Sources tells us that it is very possible for Rex Tillerson to be confirmed as secretary of state. He was confirmed by a committee this week and has therefore passed the first phase.
Recent reports suggest it's practically confirmed now.

Done and dusted.
U.S. Senate panel clears Tillerson's path to be secretary of state

There won't be a major issue preventing this.

Appears that the Republican caucus will vote a majority to confirm Tillerson as SoS this evening.
Rubio, Graham and McCain have all signalled their support. Senate only needs simple majority to pass him.
McCain, Graham & Rubio have dropped their opposition to him.
Increasing forecast because Rubio has apparently agreed to support Tillerson. http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/315634-rubio-to-vote-for-tillerson
Rubio is voting to confirm. Other than a youtube clip showing Tillerson participating in a golden shower with Russian prostitutes, this is a done deal.
He's a sure thing now. Updating from 95%.

Rubio made public his support. This seems to be closing soon.
Rubio has agreed to vote for Tillerson. He was the major hold out.

Rubio last significant holdout.  Will get deal to be named later for his vote - prob Cuba-related.  Also posturing for Pres run.  Putin unlikely to move until Tillerson confirmed. China is wildcard, but not likely to move unexpectedly/rashly.
now has backing of key Rep senators, unlikely to be hit by real scandal, Dems will fight elsewhere
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Senators McCain and Graham announced today that they will support Tillerson. That's pretty much Game, Set, Match.

A bit late in the forecast but here is mine:
John McCain and Lindsey Graham announced their support for Tillerson (after weeks of expressing public concern). It seems he's getting the needed Senate traction. Unless he withdraws, his appointment will probably be confirmed soon.

The Latest: Sen. McCain says he'll support Rex Tillerson
http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/world-news/the-latest-sen-mccain-says-hell-support-rex-tillerson/articleshow/56719875.cms The committee is narrowly split between 11 Republicans and 10 Democrats so Republicans must all hold together to vote Tillerson out favorably, unless he gets some Democratic backing. Still, a "no" vote from Rubio would not doom Tillerson's confirmation, because the nomination could go directly to the Senate floor even without a positive committee recommendation. 
http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/world-news/trump-nomination-to-lead-state-picks-up-support-in-senate/articleshow/56724270.cms

"Tillerson needs just a bare majority of votes to win approval, and it appears highly unlikely now that Tillerson will lose the three or more Republican votes that could have scuttled his nomination."
Source:  http://www.politico.com/story/2017/01/mccain-tillerson-senate-confirm-233989
Graham and McCain are both on board.  http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-tillerson-idUSKBN1560X8 The nomination will leave committee one way or another so its out of Rubio's hands.
Confirmation hearing went as well as could be expected, and there is a sense of urgency from both sides of the Senate to get squared in on the foreign affairs of America.
UPDATE for passage of time : UFPOT

Dems regretting that filibuster modification now. Seriously, I think he would be confirmed even with the old filibuster rules. He performed fairly well in his hearing.  Issues over his associations with my above water namesake, not a deal breaker for R's. Even McCain has said he will vote for confirmation.
Inch-up on no new material adverse info

The U.S. Senate confirmed the first two members of President Donald Trump's cabinet on Friday, voting overwhelmingly to approve two retired four-star Marine generals as his secretaries of defense and homeland security hours after Trump was sworn in as commander-in-chief.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-congress-mattis-idUSKBN1542VA

Probably by the end of next week.  It is usual, and actually a Good Idea, for the Senate to act quickly on major presidential appointments at the beginning of a new administration.  The Ds will cave on this one, but may block one of the lesser ones for a while.  It will make them feel less pathetic.
Republicans control the process and will confirm regardless of conflicts of interest by the the nominee or lack of qualifications.
Read comments about how nearly all cabinet nominations are confirmed, so picking it's almost certain probability.
no clear signal of congressional opposition after meeting with him
I believe that congress (the democrats) will focus on stopping different appointees

Another downgrade because I just don't know. Look, I've read "Thinking Fast and Slow" by Kahneman, "The Signal and the Noise" by Nate Silver, and "The Undoing Project" by Michael Lewis. I know about the fucking Israeli flight instructors. But I've also read "The Black Swan" by Taleb Nassim, and I'm wondering if base rates have any meaning here. There is already plenty of evidence that this is a different world: Monica Crowley has withdrawn her nomination (though not for a cabinet position), some sources are saying Puzdar is reconsidering his nomination, and a vote for Tillerson has been delayed for Monday.  A Tillerson confirmation remains highly probable, but it's foolish to think this is a sure thing at this point in time. The situation will be clearer in a week.

There have been roughly 500 cabinet appointments in US history. Only 21 of these were not confirmed by the Senate, meaning that there's slightly better than a 4% chance Tillerson won't be confirmed. However, I predict that Tillerson will be confirmed with higher probability than that, as it seems the Senate is much more interested in derailing some of Trump's less competent appointments (notably DeVos), and will basically need to conserve its outrage for the most outrageous appointees. Tillerson proved himself too slick to be a good target for a takedown during the hearings.
Shock and outrage have shown to be no barriers to the Trump administration. The appointment will go ahead.
Informed by the base rates of @pietrokc.

Though he was unaware of his own untruths during the hearing by saying the oil industry has no government subsidy and some of his decisions at EXXON were not well received, such as his decision to purchase XTO and their stock has lost strength, he will become Secretary of State because no one in the two party opposition has another contender, such as when the GOP said they wanted Kerry as Secretary of State.

Ideologically, Tillerson exemplifies DT's cabinet nominees shift to the right on economic issues. In practice, there are few, if any,  w/ Tillerson's direct hands on geopolitical contacts, including Russia, that can compare over a cycle that have had to resolve issues at a global level. It's a game changer for DT. Senate confirms. Finally, Tillerson has undisputed biz creditials that traditional Republican members must respect although, he, Wilbur Ross & Steven Munchin have no "voting records". Thus, they may not necessarily agree w/ mainstream Republicans. Each of these nominees, especially Tillerson, have a successful track record in closing transactions for the benefit of their particular biz interests. If DT doesn't blow the political sit'n out of control, Tillerson  is actually v/ well equipped to go to bat w/ the world at large, as Secretary of State. My real concern isn't Russia's Putin.  It's China. Like DT, Xi is focused, hard headed &, carries the weight of over 1bn people & his party on his shoulders. Xi has little room to maneuver from his public disclosures which are at odds w/ Tillerson's recent S. China Sea build up for example. I therefore wouldn't underestimate Xi Jinping's three fundamental messages: a trade war is a no winner situation, the one China policy is not up for discussion &, China's S. Sea position. Tillerson as well as DT seem to be driving towards a head on collision on all counts. We should expect more disequilibrium  on these fronts as both Tillerson & DT push in the other direction this year.

Elaine Chao, nominee for Secretary of Transportation
Elaine Chao appeared before the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation yesterday afternoon. Chao served as the secretary of the Labor Department under George W. Bush and as deputy secretary of transportation under George H. W. Bush. She is the spouse of Senate majority leader Mitch McConnell (R-Kentucky). As we wrote back in November, Chao, if confirmed, will likely play a role in overseeing and shepherding through Congress a $1 trillion infrastructure plan that Trump has stated he plans to make a priority of his administration. Two key discussion points in yesterday’s hearing included how to fund infrastructure projects and the possible privatization of air traffic control operations at U.S. airports.
This was what McConnell "GOT" for a Rex conformation hearing that went favorably.
With John McCain announcing he will (likely) support Tillerson the rallying point around which dissenting Republicans might gather is gone. There won't be the numbers to block him.
If there were a Rex file in Moscow we would have heard about.  Moving up over 55 and watching for schedule of private meet and greets like Schmer and Rubio

Sen. John McCain told Fox New’s Martha MacCallum that he’s leaning toward voting to confirm Rex Tillerson, President-elect Donald Trump’s nominee to head the State Department . "Some of my concerns have been satisfied, [but] I haven't made up my mind completely," McCain said. http://thehill.com/homenews/senate/314506-mccain-leans-toward-voting-for-tillerson

Base rate is: out of 109 cabinet-level nominees by last 6 presidents, 5 eventually withdrew, and only 1 was not confirmed by the Senate [1]. That non-confirmation was by a Senate controlled by the opposite party to the president; the last time the president's own party rejected their cabinet nominee was in 1925 [1]. Tillerson was nominated a month ago and shows no sign of withdrawing, with inauguration just a week away. There is this Russia nonsense but Tillerson is not accused of any actual crimes. [1] https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/its-really-hard-to-block-a-cabinet-nominee/

The US cabinet and executive branch cannot function without a legal and approved secretary of state. The United States is already going through the approval process for Rex Tillerson and should eventually be passed within the first 100 days of Trump's presidency.
As Tetlock shows almost all nominees, even those with bad confirmation hearings, get confirmed.

Rubio and 9 Democrats could stop it from being approved by Committee but the Whole Senate could vote on anyway. I expect they would and he will be approved. Russia contacts, saber rattling at China and all.
He is supported by people respected by both Republicans and Democrats.

From the Carter to Obama administrations, 91% of contested cabinet nominees ended up being nominated. And all of the 9% were rejected by a senate dominated by the opposition party. A same-party rejection has not happened since 1925. So this puts his chances in the high 90s. Is there anything to mitigate these facts? For instance, many political expectations have been overturned over the past year. Trump is not a part of the Republican establishment and Rubio may be carving out some space for himself as a leader of legislators who want to assert their independence from Trump. The grilling he gave and his expressed uncertainty over confirming Tillerson make a point. Would Rubio have anything to gain by torpedoing the nomination (even if he could)? It's early in the administration and I don't think such an outright split is yet in the cards.

https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/its-really-hard-to-block-a-cabinet-nominee/
however some republicans have already expressed their oposition to Rex Tillerson (but they are the minority)
The Republicans don't care about conflicts, questionable associations, or ethics. He will be confirmed along party lines.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

This article says it all: https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/its-really-hard-to-block-a-cabinet-nominee/ Only 9 cabinet appointees have ever been voted down by the Senate, and they were typically because of either scandal or impropriety. Neither is really the case here (Tillerson's obvious conflicts of interests don't quite merit the "scandal" label, although they are absolutely worrisome). On top of this, a Republican Senate and Tillerson's half-decent performance at the confirmation hearings (especially when he broke with Trump on issues like climate change and Russian hacking, and his promise to completely divest from his business) could even sway a Democrat or two if any Republicans get cold feet.

Mr. Tillerson represents the epitome of the Trump approach to dealing with issues of his administration.  Find the smartest, most experienced and capable person to put into the position and deal with it.  There is no one with more of a broad based exposure to world issues and players than Tillerson.  He has literally been into every country that matters and knows each of those current world leaders.  Who else is more capable?   Only thing that will get in the way is old fashioned politics where someone with their own personal political agenda lets political philosophy overrule common sense and the interests of the nation.

Feels like we're going into Alice in Wonderland. I keep thinking of the Apprentice and "off with his head" from Alice. Unless something serious gets exposed, unvoered or Buzzfeed posted, Tillerson will be confirmed.
Well choreographed answers in front of the committee. Republican backing to push those president elects choice.

- In the cabinet of a president Trump :-(, where the only consistency is inconsistency , any semblance of sanity will be accepted
- Tillerson, as the head of a global oil & gas firm, is uniquely experienced in international affairs and dealing with world leaders as O&G heads have to constantly deal with geopolitical issues more than leaders in other sectors , to the extent they have their own intelligence units.
- In this triangular diplomacy situation that seems to be emerging where the only consistency coming from trump is this "tilt" towards Russia to use as leverage against China (uncertain what the end game will be but whatever...), Tillerson will be a helpful pick even though his affinity to Vlad, that in and of itself is the chief reason for concern.  
- Democrats have lost the fire to fight and/or are saving whatever fight they have in them for other more concerning appointments (they didn't do anything against a more serious threat, Sessions, so i don't know what they're waiting for).

Rex Tillerson faces a vocal but seriously weakened opposition from environmentalists who oppose the possibility/probability that he could undermine their hopes and dreams of promoting alternative energy as a major component of alleviating the impact of climate change.  Perhaps, a more readily transparent and critical concern that could lead to scuttling his appointment revolves around his close ties with Putin and Exxon's economic stakes in Russia as well as in the Middle East.  These issues have aroused concern of many Republicans (most vocally Senators John McCain and Lindsey Graham) who could join a majority of Democrats to block his appointment.  I believe that Tillerson's depth of  awareness concerning international conditions he has had to contend with in his long tenure at Exxon allows him to effectively answer difficult questions that, coupled with his basic gravitas, will at the end of the day, win Senate approval.   I, as a committed opponent of dependence on fossil fuels, paradoxically believe that Tillerson will have the political savvy to convince President elect Trump that he should not remove US participation from continuing in its current role as  a member of the Paris Climate Agreement.
he will take the longest but will eventually be confirmed, Trump is stubborn, he won't withdraw a nominee...

This Jan. 12, CNN article, http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/12/politics/jeff-merkley-rex-tillerson/, notes Tillerson's mixed reception during congressional questioning. It may be possible that he does not get confirmed at all. Lowering my probability estimate on this.

Typically, nominees get confirmed, especially in a President's first term unless the screw up their confirmation hearings.  He seems like a careful and thoughtful person, unlike Trump, and I believe he will be welcomed by both parties.

According to FiveThirtyEight, nominees are not frequently blocked, and this year there can be no filibuster, making it even more unlikely [1]. I think Tillerson's nomination will be given priority after all politically appointed ambassadors leave their posts on January 20. [1] https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/its-really-hard-to-block-a-cabinet-nominee/
Newspaper articles online, statements made and discussed by Trump and others in reaction.

Yes, the man with a Bond villian's name will continue to be dumbfounded by questions about international affairs even he has all that experience working with foreign powers, and it will be good enough to get him through.
While he gave answers that were of concern about China and appears not knowledgeable on important issues the partisan split will confirm him. Plus for Dems is not a total denial climate change.

Another downgrade. I'm finding more ways the nomination can go all wrong. If Rubio votes against Tillerson, then the nomination doesn't get out of committee. McConnell can still force a vote, but if Rubio, McCain and Graham all vote no, then the nomination goes down. I can tell a story where Rubio and McCain, who have both been bruised by Trump, do this purely as a power play. Is this likely? No. But I'm beginning to realise that a Trump presidency is a different world and I would be foolish to be certain about anything.  Note, if Rubio votes for Tillerson in committee then I think it is pretty much a done deal.
He will be confirmed simply because Republicans will not vote rationally. They will stick together. It's more important for them to show a united front than to behave rationally.
Republicans are in majority, Tillersons view are in line with Pres Trump, not a lot of nominees were rejected in history
Republicans like him, he gives money, and even as a liberal I think he will be good for the role so I see little reason for him to not be confirmed.
I can see the money flowing for McCain, Graham and boy Rubio.......so it is not going to be easy but it is a done deal.
Surprisingly poorly informed on some matters, such as religious screening.  Unsure of Rubio's opposition and its consequences.  Even so, he still likely has the votes for confirmation.
They have similar policies and agree on a lot
Mr Tillerson seems to have the same views on foreign policy as the deep state.
Opposition will surface from politicians (like McCain) to get on the record concerning threats from Russia but I don't see this being a fight that will last long.
Not enough votes against his nomination.
Barring the release of incriminating information, Tillerson will be confirmed.
There's no reason he won't be appointed.

Of all the appointments, Tillerson appears to be handling it the best in my opinion. His finances are being sorted and his opinions on key topics so far have been (suspiciously) balanced.  But, perhaps I'm not estimating correctly how his past experiences with Russia will play out in the hearings and/or if something negative will suddenly surface.

I think if trump likes the guy then hell put him in his cabinet no matter if hes good at what he does or not. trump isnt smart enough to pick and choose professional people that are trusted to make right decisons.
It seems that Trump as well as many others favor Tillerson. It is very likely that he will be confirmed.
Tillerson and the committee spent today circling around each other looking for a good spot to kiss each other on their nether cheeks.  They will succeed, and he'll get the nod.
If Trump likes him then why wouldn't he put Tillerson in as secretary of state. It seems like a hot topic but I think Trump likes the ties with Russia
Trump wants a proven business man like himself to by his side in increasing American production and bringing back industrialization.
He will be approved because the house and senate are mainly Republican so it will make it easy.
Trump is a major businessman and would love to have another one of his kind in the office. I think it is very likely that he will be approved for office.
It is more then likely Rex Tillerson will be confirmed by the senate within the the 30th of April. This is because he is favored by many people and someone needs to step up to the plate quick.

Going from 50>90 today. Had a tough time from Rubio, but generally has said the right things on Russia to offer reassurance. He did diverge from the Trump position on several matters, which opens up the question of will he deliver on his words or revert to the Trump position after confirmation, but those are not relevant to the question being asked here. In sum, he hasn't scared off enough GOP for them to create a decisive bloc with the Dems to stop the appointment.

Yes I think there is a high chance of Tillerson being confirmed as secretary of state. Trump has seemed to being having close ties with him. This choice can greatly affect the next four years that Trump is in office.
Could well be so, as Tillerson is a friend of Putin, and trump admires Poetin.
Yes, Trump seems to favor Tillerson and seems adamant to have him on his cabinet.
No withdrawal. Good answers except for Putin's enemies question.
I think that Rex will be confirmed in the first 100 days because of the fact that he is a important man and he could be futile in the future on board with the senate. He will be chosen.
Yes because trump wants to get him in office as soon as possible

He is already the biggest front runner for the postilion there is no doubt that Trump will have Tillerson placed. It is already a republican-controlled Senate, so it would take a big event for nominees to fail confirmation.
I think that there is a chance he will be secretary but there will be strong opposition from the Republican party.
He is already the biggest front runner for the postilion and considering his ties with Russia trump will definitely go for it.
No doubt that Trump will have Tillerson placed in the position. He can't really be stopped because it is ultimately his decision.
With a Republican-controlled Senate, it would take a seismic event for nominees to fail confirmation from a Republican president(-elect).

President-elect Trump will without a doubt have Rex Tillerson officially confirmed into Senate. Considering the fact that Trump has already been in suspiciously close relations with Russia, it shouldn't be a shock if Tillerson gets in by April. Also, no one should forget the business mindset Trump possesses and his intentions to rebuild this country. Especially if he is being generous to oil companies.
I believe he will be in government as Secretary of State because of his heavy influence on the US today. He also has friendly relations with Russia.
Even though he has relations with Russia he is a good candidate for Secretary of State
Rex Tillerson is a good candidate for secretary of state
Despite his friendly relationship with Putin, there's nothing compelling to disqualify him.

Yes, I believe that Donald Trump will not get Will Tillerson without a fight. Tillerson would fit perfectly with Trump and his growing club of billionaires. Trump has referred to Tillerson as more than a business executive to him. He said he was a world-class player and that he was in charge of the largest company in the world. One advantage of Tillerson he said is that he knows the players very well.
He's the pick, but there's a lot of opposition.

CNN is reporting that the top US intelligence groups have informed DTrump that Russia may have collected enough information to blackmail him.  Dropping forecast until there is some proof that Trump is not being controlled by Russian agents.

Yes because Trump is very similar to Tillerson as in they are both wealthy business and I believe Trump would like having Tillerson by his side.

Trump is a man of business and so is ExxonMobil CEO Rex Tillerson. They will both most likely be powering the United States in the near future for the good. I do think that he will because he has ties to Trump and Russia. Russia is not bad, they are an essential ally not enemy and they are needed to defeat terrorism groups forming larger. This is why I think he will be confirmed be Senate.

Yes.  Rex Tillerson will be confirmed by the Senate as Secretary of State before 30 April 2017.  Rex Tillerson is a very wealthy CEO of Exxon and has many of the same views as President Elect Trump.  There will be many hard questions about his relationship with Russian President Putin, but the Republican Senate will approve the appointment.

Lowering my forecast from 98% to 90% because of the following from 538 site: https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/its-really-hard-to-block-a-cabinet-nominee/. The piece makes two points I wasn't aware of. First, the nominations cannot be filibustered, which means it is entirely in control of the Republicans. However it also points out that while the last time a nomination had been rejected was in 1989, five picks have been withdrawn,  including three of Obama's. That is a substantially different base rate. Trump administration attempts to pass candidates through nomination hearings before the are properly vetted. From Today's FT (p3):
... (Office of Government ethics) OGE director Walter Shaub said that the current confirmation schedule was "of great concern" and had created an unprecedented situation for his office.
     "the schedule has created undue pressure on OGE's staff and agency ethics officials to rush through these important reviews. More significantly, it has left some of the nominees with potentially unknown or unresolved ethics issues shortly before their scheduled hearings...
     "I am not aware of any occasion in the four decades since OGE was established when the Senate held a confirmation hearing before the nominee had completed the ethics review process"  ...  As long as I remain director, OGE's staff and agency ethics officials will not succumb to pressure to cut corners and ignore conflicts of interest."

The major questions around Tillerson are his alleged closeness to Putin and how he'd treat environmental matters given his oil industry background. The first are a potential bipartisan concern, the second likely more of a objection from the Democrats. Beyond those two substantive matters there is also the more narrow political matter of whether his very high profile makes him a deliberate target for efforts to block a Trump candidate - and this can be both a GOP and a Democrat point of optics. There will be a strong Dem No block given the three points above, but is this the nomination they choose as their Hill to die on? Secondly, how many Republicans might split off?  On the closeness to Putin point I do look on much of this as a distraction. It came with his role. Similarly lobbying against Russia sanctions, especially where his company would take a big hit, is part of his role, rather than an indication of pro-Russia sympathies. His visible efforts to divest from Exxon should be confirmed speak very clearly to his character and pragmatism which should offset some of these worries. The question is whether the wave of hostility toward Russia (and I am very much a Russia hawk) is going to be enough to sway a few Republican Senators who want to be seen as being extra tough on Russia, and how many might be emboldened by principled opposition to Trump. I'm currently of the view that there will not be a full Dem opposition so the number of GOP that need to vote No could be >10. I suspect that would be a tough number to achieve.
Priority is energy and cooperation with Russia. Everyone is tired from Obama-Putin personal feud.

Baseline:  Congress has confirmed well over 500 nominees over the course of US history.  Only 8 nominees (<1.5%) were not confirmed and none of these were for Secretary of State.   Tillerson comes on the recommendation of Robert Gates, who is himself well-regarded by both parties.

Tillerson has demonstrated, by being a successful businessman in an international market, that he can negotiate and cooperate with other countries.
His close ties to Russia (and the Middle East) could actually be the best thing for the US right now. Relations between the US and Russia have been deteriorating for years, and by improving them, the US can facilitate co-operation between Russia and the rest of the world. For example, the assault on Ukraine in 2014, relations between Russia and other European countries deteriorated. This has been further exacerbated by the role currently being played in Syria by the Russian military. A secretary of state with a good relationship with Russia gives an opportunity for the US to improve ties with Russia and the rest of the world.
